measured_by: Asian Disease Problem risky-choice framing task
justification: The article recounts that in Tversky and Kahneman’s (1981) Asian disease scenario participants chose between a sure option and a probabilistic option, and the pattern of those choices (e.g., 72 % preferring Program A vs. 78 % preferring Program D) was used to infer whether they were behaving in a risk-averse or risk-seeking manner.

measured_by: Participants’ self-reported interpretation categories of numerical quantifiers in Mandel (2014) experiments
justification: The text states that Mandel (2014) assessed framing effects "after taking account of participants' reported interpretations of quantifiers (as lower-bounded, bilateral, or even upper-bounded)," indicating that respondents’ explicit classification of the numbers served as the measure of their quantifier interpretation.

measured_by: Explicated Valence Account tasks manipulating predicate expressions (e.g., ‘saved’, ‘die’, ‘not saved’) in Tombu & Mandel (2015)
justification: According to the article, Tombu and Mandel (2015) "present a series of experimental results" in which varying predicate wording changed how positive or negative an option seemed, and participants’ perceptions of which option was riskier were recorded, making this manipulation the instrument for measuring perceived valence and associated risk.
